objects.agworkervisas: yes
objects.caption: Calif. Congressional member Dianne Feinstein - (D-California)
objects.stemvisas: yes
objects.citizenship: yes - pathway to earned citizenship that requires undocumented immigrants pay taxes and fines, pass background checks and learn English

objects.agworkervisas: yes, but workers should have access to pathway to citizenship
objects.caption: Calif. Congressional member Karen Bass - (D-Los Angeles)
objects.family-basedvisas: should include gay and lesbian partners
objects.e-verify: We should provide tools for employers to ensure the people they hire are eligible to work in the United States while making sure there are appropriate penalties for companies that knowingly hire undocumented workers once a system is in place.
objects.stemvisas: yes, but not at expense of diversity visas: Federal immigration policy should facilitate, not restrict the movement of highly skilled workers into the United States. We should provide a sufficient number of highly skilled immigrant visas to respond to the economic needs of the country. However we should not do this at the expense of the Diversity Visas Program, which is credited with providing an opportunity for immigrants from countries deemed to have low rates of immigration to the United States like those in Sub Saharan Africa.
objects.citizenship: yes - It is not practical to deport 11 million undocumented immigrants living within our borders.

objects.caption: Calif. Congressional member Xavier Becerra - (D-Los Angeles)
objects.citizenship: One of 8 House members negotiating immigration bill that includes pathway to citizenship

objects.caption: Calif. Congressional member Ami Bera - (D-Sacramento)

objects.agworkervisas: Support discussions between farm workers and agricultural industry that would provide protections for farm workers and pathway to citizenship.
objects.caption: Calif. Congressional member Julia Brownley - (D-Ventura)
objects.family-basedvisas: should include gay and lesbian partners
objects.e-verify: Yes, but it has to be reliable and not overly burden businesses, or get in the way those eligible to work.
objects.stemvisas: Supportive of increasing. Need to find the right number so that businesses have access to the skilled workers they need without taking away jobs from Americans.
objects.citizenship: yes

objects.caption: Calif. Congressional member Ken Calvert - (R-Riverside)
objects.e-verify: yes, mandatory
objects.citizenship: "Some kind of legal status, though not citizenship, for undocumented immigrants already in the country if they meet a number of conditions. These conditions must include that the individual has lived in the U.S. for a certain period of time, a background check to ensure only law abiding individuals are permitted to remain, payment of all back taxes and an appropriate fine, and passing a basic English proficiency exam.”

objects.agworkervisas: open to something like that if it works and is enforced without too much excessive cost - then it becomes a subsidy to ag industry
objects.dreamact: "there's a lot of distinction being drawn now between people who came here illegally and the children of those people and I think that's a distinction which is credible."
objects.caption: Calif. Congressional member John Campbell - (R-Irvine)
objects.e-verify: "you obviously need something like that"
objects.citizenship: yes, but - "some we don't want here, others that will have a path to legalization, and others a path to citizenship"

objects.agworkervisas: yes - supports comprehensive immigration reform that ensures a stable agriculture workforce, protects the rights of agriculture workers; and provides an earned path to citizenship
objects.caption: Calif. Congressional member Lois Capps - (D-Santa Barbara)
objects.family-basedvisas: She has co-sponsored standalone legislation to change current policy regarding gay and lesbian partners because our current policy is discriminatory and ineffective.
objects.e-verify: does not support mandatory e-verify in the absence of comprehensive immigration reform
objects.stemvisas: Congresswoman Capps’ district is home to world class research institutions like UCSB and Cal Poly that contribute significantly to our local economy and have spawned numerous high tech small businesses. She support reforms to the current STEM visa program that help foster economic growth and innovation.
objects.citizenship: earned path to citizenship

objects.caption: Calif. Congressional member Tony Cardenas - (D-North Hollywood, Sun Valley)

objects.othervisaissues: "The pie should be larger. We have visas that go unused and we should at least have a provision there to use up the quota that already exists."

objects.family-basedvisas: must be reformed: "we have a broken system where people are waiting over 20 years to bring their loved ones from the homeland. Families are what makes people strong."
objects.e-verify: "We need to have a system that actually works. ANd there are a lot of problems with E-verify."
objects.stemvisas: "We benefit greatly if we are able to have STEM visas which would allow those who are educated in America to stay here and keep their innovations and their inventions here."
objects.citizenship: "must have a roadmap to citizenship for the 11 million residents that are in the shadows"

objects.citizenship: yes - pathway to citizenship as all immigrants before them have had, provided they go to the back of the line and pay any reasonable fines.

objects.caption: Calif. Congressional member Darrell Issa - (R-Vista)
objects.e-verify: "at least mandatory E-verify with strong penalties. Supports work site enforcement to prevent benefits like Medicare, Medicaid, Social Security, welfare, aid to families with dependent children
objects.citizenship: yes, but - The 11 million here fall into 3 categories: "at least one of the 11 million should be allowed to stay and if they choose to at some point become a citizen; at least one of those people should be ordered out as a criminal, as an undesirable of many sorts; and at least one of them should be a guestworker, given a permit to remain here, to work, in some cases with family, and in many cases without the ability to have additional non-working dependents.The question is how many in each." "If you allow someone to remain in this country for the rest of their life, they cannot in my opinion under any circumstances, be treated as a second-class citizen." Cites 4 examples: exclusion of African-Americans as citizens at country's founding, exclusion of Native Americans until half a century plus after African-Americans granted it, Chinese exclusion act

objects.misc: As a country we spend more money on immigration enforcement than on the FBI, Secret Service, Drug Enforcement Administration, U.S. Marshal Service, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives combined. Enforcement is at an all-time high and increasing it would be a waste of taxpayer dollars.
objects.bordersecurity: As a country we spend more money on immigration enforcement than on the FBI, Secret Service, Drug Enforcement Administration, U.S. Marshal Service, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives combined. Enforcement is at an all-time high and increasing it would be a waste of taxpayer dollars.
objects.caption: Calif. Congressional member Barbara Lee - (D-Oakland)
objects.e-verify: E-Verify is a flawed system that would essentially allow employers to act as immigration agents by requiring them to determine an individual's legal status. E-Verify allows employers to exploit workers by paying them under the table and getting around other workplace protections.

And we can do so in a way that doesn't require employers to try to stereotype people."
